column1: Mandeville is the capital and largest town in the parish of Manchester in the county of Middlesex
column3: the town had an estimated population of 50
column5: and including the immediate suburbs within a radius of 16 km (9.9 mi) the total population is about 72
column6: 000. It is located on an inland plateau at an altitude of 628 m (2061 feet)
column7: and is 103 km (64 mi) west of Kingston. It is the only parish capital of Jamaica not located on the coast or on a major river.

column4: elegant early nineteenth-century houses line the winding streets in the town centre.

column1: In the suburbs of the town many large houses have been built by returning residents from North America and the United Kingdom on an ad hoc basis.  Developers have complemented these with large housing developments
column2: some of which are constructed as gated communities.  Prominent suburbs and surrounding areas include Ingleside
column16: Greenvale and Marshalls Pen.Mandeville is a major commercial centre
column17: and is the location of Northern Caribbean University (formerly West Indies College)
column18: a Seventh-day Adventist institution of higher learning.

column1: The mayor of Mandeville is Brenda Ramsay.
The town was laid out in 1816
column3: the eldest son of the Duke of Manchester
column4: who was then governor of Jamaica.

column1: Many of the original buildings can still be seen such as the courthouse
column2: an impressive building of cut limestone with a horseshoe staircase and a raised portico supported by Doric columns and built in 1820. The staircase was added in about 1900.

column1: Many of Jamaica's oldest businesses were started in Mandeville; the Mandeville Hotel
column2: one of the oldest in the Caribbean
column3: began operations in 1875. Its golf club
column4: founded as the Manchester Golf Club in 1868
column5: was the first golf course in the Caribbean. The first "free library" in Jamaica was established in 1938
column6: and is the oldest Parish Library.

column1: The growth of the town was given a substantial stimulus when the Alcan Bauxite Company in a joint venture with the Jamaican Government opened its Kirkvine works nearby at Williamsfield in 1957. It built houses at Mandeville for its then mostly expatriate staff. The relatively high wages lured many educated Jamaicans there. Subsequently
column2: the town has seen an influx of Jamaican residents returning from abroad.
